title: Events
text:
December 2, 2025 - Free SCGIS Webinar:
Advancing Conservation and Community Resilience with Thermal and Hyperspectral Remote Sensing: Applications from NASA’s ECOSTRESS and EMIT Missions
This upcoming webinar will first highlight the use of ECOSTRESS data for urban heat analysis and mitigation. It will then introduce conservation-related applications of EMIT data, including habitat as well as plant trait and diversity mapping. Finally, the last presentation will explore a combined use of both EMIT and ECOSTRESS data for assessing pre-wildfire risk in Los Angeles, California. https://us06web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_P-WgfwuYQButrB-Cdjgm0Q#/registration
January, 2026 - SCGIS Vancouver Meeting
We are currently planning the first meeting for SCGIS Vancouver members. This will consist of a workshop followed by a more general meeting of thechapter.
In this first workshop we will generate and gather spatial layers from local open data portals and set them up into a cloud ready map database powered by open source QGIS and QField[Cloud] in a conservation setting, with a case study in a local Vancouver park!
These maps can be synced between field users on mobile (collecting the data) and desktop to provide real time updates on both ends.
Exact date and details to follow!

July 7-10, 2026 – SCGIS Annual Conference
Estes Park Center, Rocky Mountain National Park, CO, USA

Stay tuned for more information!
https://www.scgis.org/conference

November 19, 2025 - GIS Day
IKB Library, University of British Columbia, BC, CA

GIS Day is an annual worldwide celebration of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology and community, dedicated to promoting geospatial literacy, education, and awareness. This event brings together students, educators, researchers, and industry professionals who share an interest in geography, cartography, remote sensing, spatial data science, and related fields.

title: SCGIS Vancouver
text:
Welcome to the homepage for the newly formed (est. November 2025) Vancouver, BC Chapter of the Society for Conservation GIS.
Our chapter is an affiliated chapter of the Society for Conservation GIS (SCGIS). SCGIS helps bring together conservation practitioners and GIS technology by supporting communication and networking, scholarships, and training across the world through a system of connected chapters in various cities and countries. Membership is open to anyone looking to engage in the GIS conservation community.











About Us



This group aims to bring together the community of conservation-related Geographic Information System (GIS) practitioners across Vancouver and the broader region of southern British Columbia. Membership to our Chapter is free and open to anyone! Check out our Members Map below (anonymous), or learn more on our About Us page. You can sign up to be a member by joining our Mailing List (Below).



















Events



SCGIS Vancouver hosts a variety of events, including talks from conservation and GIS specialists and groups, hands-on workshops, outdoor citizen science, and social mixers. Check out past and upcoming events here! Be sure to sign up for our mailing list (above) and follow us on social media for updates.

title: About Us
text:
The Society for Conservation GIS is an all-volunteer U.S. based non-profit organization focused on advancing conservation GIS globally by building and supporting conservation GIS practioners (and enthusiasts!).
Learn more about their mission here



SGIS brings together GIS enthusiasts across academia, the public sector, and private/consulting groups. Chapter membership is free and open to all - all you need to do is sign up for our Mailing List! We also encourage you to consider paid membership to SCGIS, which gives you access to members-only content and resources like the SCGIS ArcGIS Online account, discounted ESRI software & training, and more.









The Chapter representatives run the week-by-week operations of our Chapter. If you have any questions about SCGIS, ideas for an event, or would like to contribute to the Chapter in any way - you can contact them at scgis.canada.vancouver@gmail.com.



Ramon is a postdoctoral research fellow in the Integrated Remote Sensing Studio (IRSS), at the University of British Columbia (UBC). His research explores the use of multi-source remote sensing and geospatial datasets towards enhanced monitoring of the carbon cycle across boreal landscapes. During his time at UBC, Ramon has been involved in supporting a wide variety of undergraduate and graduate GIS courses, course development initiatives, and serves as a Teaching Assistant (TA) Training Coordinator for the Faculty of Forestry. As part of SCGIS Vancouver, he provides technical expertise on satellite remote sensing and looks forward to supporting local GIS practitioners in growing their skillset, highlighting their work, and connecting with their community.



Sadie is a PhD student in UBC Forestry, where her graduate work has focused on applying remote sensing to disturbance ecology across British Columbia. Her current research investigates how drone-based lidar can support operational pyro-silviculture prescriptions to reduce wildfire risk. Sadie is deeply engaged in scientific education and communication, having developed climate change education materials for students from primary school through university. Through SCGIS, Sadie hopes to build community and uplift early-career scientists and conservationists.



Liam is a PhD Candidate at UBC Forestry working in remote sensing. His research focuses on integrating lidar (from drones and aircraft) into silvicultural practices. He is also involved in local conservation efforts at several regional parks including aiding in their integration of GIS into ecosystem restoration. As part of SCGIS Vancouver Liam hopes to bring technical and regional knowledge to help build the capacity of the GIS conservation community around Vancouver and beyond.




Advisory members support the Chapter with their technical support and great ideas!



For 20+ years, Trevor has been combining geospatial and field data to produce maps, understand change, make predictions, and assist decision makers across a variety of forested landscapes. Trevor’s work as a scientist, educator, program developer, and team builder involves communities, conservation non-profits, Universities, governments, and private sector organizations, and includes 20 countries across five continents. Trevor is Adjunct Faculty at UBC, a co-founder and the Global Technical Lead for Tayo Climate Partners, and the Blue Forests and Geospatial advisor for Blue Ventures Conservation.

title: Resources
text:
Below is a curated list of spatial data, and conservation related resources for Vancouver, southern British Columbia, and beyond. This page is intended to be a living document, growing with our community.
If you have a useful GIS/conservation resource you don’t see listed, please let us know


These are primary, large-scale open data portals for municipal, regional, provincial, and federal GIS data.

City of Vancouver Open Data Portal

The city’s portal for high-resolution municipal data, including urban ecology, green spaces, street trees, and utilities.

Metro Vancouver Open Data Portal

Provides regional-scale data that cross municipal boundaries in the lower mainland, such as regional parks, land use, and remote sensing data.

BC Data Catalogue

Contains datasets from B.C. government ministries, including wildlife, forestry, water, administrative boundaries, and base maps.

Government of Canada Open Data Portal

The federal portal for national-scale datasets. This portal contains data related to tidal fisheries (DFO), national parks (Parks Canada), federal species at risk (SARA), and climate (Environment and Climate Change Canada).
